src.fi.tuni.tamk.tiko.paajarvilauri

Class Game.Ai

  • java.lang.Object
    • src.fi.tuni.tamk.tiko.paajarvilauri.Game.Ai
  • Enclosing class:
    Game

    class Game.Ai
extends java.lang.Object
    Inner class, that has purpose of determining the computer's next move.

    • Field Detail

      • AiRating

        int AiRating
        "Legacy" variable, not actually used in this version.

        There might be some comments still referring to it so i'm still leaving it here. Basically its function was to determine the probablitiy (100 being totally sure as in 100percent) of Ai making the best possible move it can. Lower difficulty ratings would have had AiRating lower, where it would make some other move, but I abandoned the idea haflway cosing the AiMakeMove() method because the task would have been surprisigly difficult to maintain throughout the different directions Ai could take their move towards.

      • humanCloseVictoryBoard

        int[][] humanCloseVictoryBoard
        Holds information about human's near victories.

        Identical to the size of char[][] board. Empty tiles that have victory ahead if 2 more tiles are put, will have a value of 1. Or more, depending the amount of directions that there will be a close victory like that. All the other y,x coordinates will hold the value of 0.

      • computerCloseVictoryBoard

        int[][] computerCloseVictoryBoard
        Same as humanCloseVictoryBoard but for the computer.

      • priorityCaseBoard

        int[][] priorityCaseBoard
        Holds information about what tiles Ai thinks are good to occupy.

        Doesn't take into account strategic moves but checks if there is good spots for enemy's next move. Can be often used mixed with other boards initiated here, to determine the definitive best move. The higher the score in the position, the better move Ai thinks it is. NOTE: As of version 2019-1210 this information is great on 4 and 3 target scored games, but makes computers default moves a bit worse on higher target scored games.

      • hiPriorityBoard

        int[][] hiPriorityBoard
        Gathers information different to other boards initiated here.

        This board was originally created to support the AiRating's full functionality, where computer might choose some of the next best moves instead of always the best one. That is why it will hold the best move that can be made with the value 1, next best move as 2 and so on. There might not be many numbers on it though, since now computer just tries to find that 1 definitive move. 0s in this board would be something that computer don't consider good moves to pursue at all, except when there is not even one positive number on board.

      • modifiedPriorityBoard

        int[][] modifiedPriorityBoard
        Usually the final board that determines the move.

        Holds the information from the mixed results when applying other boards contents together, based on the priority order in AiMakeMove() -method.

      • modifiedPriorityBoardSuccess

        boolean modifiedPriorityBoardSuccess
        Whether computer found one move that is better than others.

        If not, then it will be random generated among the positions that ai can't decide if one is better than the other.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Ai

        public Ai()
        The default and the only constructor, since AiRating was abandoned.

    • Method Detail

      • AiMakeMove

        public int[] AiMakeMove()
        Determines the computers next move's coordinates.

        There is lot of information in the java codes comments. Never returns coordinates that do not hold an empty tile.

        Returns:
        coordinates as int[]{y,x} array that computer's next move is gonna take place in.

      • applyAnotherBoard

        public int[][] applyAnotherBoard(int[][] boardToModify,
                                 int[][] cvBoard)
        Mixes an existing "Ai"-board, like HiPriorityBoard with another one.

        Applies changes to first board (boardToModify) based on the values in the second bord (cvBoard). If there are no mutual coordinates in both boards, the boardToModify remains unchanged. If there are multiple values in the second player that have higher rating than all the other mutual coordinates, only they will remain in the board that is returned, and all other values will be 0. If there is only one mutual tile left, it will be the move the Ai is going to make.

        Parameters:
        boardToModify - board that determines the possible coordinates
        cvBoard - the board that is applied on to boardToModify
        Returns:
        board that has the changes made to boardToModify.

      • buildCloseBoards

        public void buildCloseBoards()
        Fills up humanCloseVictoryBoard and computerCloseVictoryBoard.

        More info on these variables that are initiated in Ai class.

      • buildPriorityCaseBoard

        public void buildPriorityCaseBoard()
        Fills up priorityCaseBoard.

        More info on Ai Class where the array is initiated.

      • getCoordinates

        public int[] getCoordinates(int[][] coBoard)
        Returns the coordiantes of the only possible move Ai thinks is best.

        Method should only take a board that has only one coordinate left on it. If there are multiple, getCoordiantesOfRandomMove(int [][]) should be used instead.

        Parameters:
        coBoard - ModifiedPriorityBoard with only one value other than 0.
        Returns:
        int[]{y,x} coordinates of the next move

      • getCoordinatesOfRandomMove

        public int[] getCoordinatesOfRandomMove(int[][] raBoard)
        Returns one random moves coordinates based on options in param board

        This method should used on a board that has multiple indexes that are other than 0. It has equal chance to choose any one of those options.

        Parameters:
        raBoard - modifiedPriorityBoard or hiPriorityBoard
        Returns:
        int[]{y,x} coordinates of next move

      • priorityCaseScore

        public int priorityCaseScore(int newY,
                             int newX)
        Returns an integer that is added in the coordinates in priorityBoard

        All 4 directions are actually always added to the score. NOTE: this method's scores could be edited to abtain better Ai for the program. Maybe it could be added to have different types of calculating the score, since right now, as in version 2019-1012 it is best used in games that have 4 or 3 tiles as their target score. This is because it doesn't manage to favor building a high number of tiles in a row as easily as putting them all chunked up in one center place next to the other. Only then closeVictoryBoard check will force Ai to start making more offensive moves.

        Parameters:
        newY - Y-coordinates of the tile whose score is calculated
        newX - X-coordinates of the tile whose score is calculated
        Returns:
        score based on how good Ai thinks the move is based on one of the four directions, and their opposite directions.

      • priorityCaseScoreDirection

        public int priorityCaseScoreDirection(int dir,
                                      int newY,
                                      int newX)

      • areThereNonZeroes

        public boolean areThereNonZeroes(int[][] array)
        Checks if 2d int array has any other values than zeroes in it.

        Will go through the array and return true in case there is a number other than the default 0 in any of its indexes. It is used to check if there is need to take humanVictoryBoard or ComputerVictoryBoard into account when determining best possible ai-moves.

        Parameters:
        array - one "victoryBoard" will be given as a parameter
        Returns:
        true, if there are any values other than 0 in it.

      • toHowManyDirectionsIsThisMoveCloseToAwinningMove

        public int toHowManyDirectionsIsThisMoveCloseToAwinningMove(char ownSide,
                                                            int posY,
                                                            int posX)
        Uses checkCloseVictoryCase() in all possible directions to get score

        Will calculate a score, that will be put into priorityBoards index. All coordinates in that board, which are not empty in char[][] board will be given a score. The bigger the score, the better move Ai thinks it would be for this player.

        Parameters:
        ownSide - Player's tile, whose priorities are being determined.
        posY - Coordinate-y of the position to be scored
        posX - Coordinate-x of the position to be scored
        Returns:
        score that is total of all directions in the method checkCloseVictoryCase().

      • checkCloseToVictoryCase

        public int checkCloseToVictoryCase(int dir,
                                   int newY,
                                   int newX)
        Checks in how many directions there is a close victory case.(2-tile)

        "Close victory case" means a case, where there is a victory not yet achieved, and can't be achieved on the next move, but CAN be achieved a move after that if not stopped by the other player. This method will be always called in 4 directions after one another.

        Parameters:
        dir - Direction where the check starts to take place. After that it will continue to check it in the opposite direction.
        newY - CoordinateY of the tile that is checked
        newX - CoordinateX of the tile that is checked
        Returns:
        true if there is a (targetScore-2) tiles in a row.

      • coordinatesOfPriorityNo

        public int[] coordinatesOfPriorityNo(int indexValue)
        Originally made to give possiblity to obtain other coordinate than the best possible move, but since AiRating idea was abandoned, this remained as a version, where it is used only to get the indexValue 1 from a board, if available. If there is no 1 in the board, it will return -1,-1, which can not be used and should be caught in later checks.

        Parameters:
        indexValue - should always be 1 at the programs current state.
        Returns:
        coordinates int[]{y,x} which will be ai:s next move.
